title: Aurora proclaims itself “Safest Large City in Colorado,” but is that true?
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania

summary:
The self-proclaimed “Safest Large City in Colorado” is holding on to its title by a thread — and perhaps shouldn’t claim the distinction at all, experts said.
Aurora has for several years billed itself as the safest city in Colorado with a population higher than 250,000 — a category that includes only Denver, Colorado Springs and Aurora — and backed the claim with crime rates calculated from data collected annually by the FBI.
“I still believe Aurora is the safest large city in the state,” Mayor Mike Coffman said Wednesday.
On Feb. 1, the department launched a 14-person task force to focus on identifying and targeting violent crime, Brown said.
He declined to discuss the “Safest Large City in Colorado” mantra, but public information Officer Matthew Longshore said the narrowed gap between the crime rates in Denver, Colorado Springs and Aurora may be attributed in part to Aurora’s rapid population growth.

title: Finally! Denver sees first snow, precipitation in nearly a month
authors: Science For The Denver Post. He Has His Certification In Broadcast Meteorology Mississippi State University
He Also Holds A Broadcasters' Seal Of Approval The National Weather Association. He Works Full-Time As A Broadcast Meteorologist At Weathernation

summary:
For the first time in nearly a month, Denver officially saw measurable rain and snow on Monday, snapping a 30-day snow- and precipitation-free streak in the city.
According to the National Weather Service, Denver’s official climate site at Denver International Airport saw a half inch of snow and slightly over a tenth of an inch of precipitation on Monday.
Denver International Airport received 0.5" of snowfall between 5 and 6 pm with 0.13" of precipitation for the day.
That was higher than the few flakes that most of central Denver saw on Monday afternoon.
That means that Monday’s 0.13 inches of precipitation means Denver is only about a quarter inch below average, despite the 30-day dry streak.

title: Aurora joins a handful of Colorado communities that support refugee resettlement
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — Aurora’s council on Monday unanimously approved a resolution in support of refugee resettlement there, taking a step now required of state and local governments if they want to accept refugees under the Trump administration.
Aurora joins a handful of other metro-area governing bodies in the state that have approved similar language in recent months:ArvadaArapahoe CountyCentennialDenverGoldenLittletonPresident Donald Trump issued an executive order last year that requires state and local governments to express an explicit desire to receive refugees in their communities.
Communities must restate their support each year.
For 2020, the deadline to opt in is Jan. 21.
Jared Polis has joined 41 other states in expressing support for refugee resettlement, writing in a letter to the Trump administration that Colorado is “committed to refugee resettlement and is eager to assist and support refugees’ successful integration into our communities.”The state’s legislature also passed a bill last year that placed Colorado’s Refugee Service Program into law.

title: Rent In Colorado: Prices Climbed In 2019
summary:
Rent costs are on the rise across the nation, according to the first National Rent Report of 2020, compiled by Apartment List.
Nationally, rent costs increased 1.4 percent from December 2018 to December 2019; however, some cities actually are bucking the trend and seeing rent costs fall.
Colorado is among states where rent costs increased in 2019.
According to the report, rent increased 1.6 percent from December 2018 to December 2019.
These are the top 10 cities with the fastest rent growth in the last five years:Stockton, California Colorado Springs, Colorado Mesa, Arizona Arlington, Texas Henderson, Nevada Tampa, Florida Aurora, Colorado Phoenix, Arizona Sacramento, California Anaheim, CaliforniaNationally, rent costs increased 11.3 percent since 2014.

title: After a decade of dramatic gains, metro Denver home prices expected to slow in 2020
authors: Aldo Svaldi Has Worked At The Denver Post Since His Coverage Areas Have Included Residential Real Estate
The Colorado Economy. He'S Also Worked For Financial Times Energy
summary:
Metro Denver home prices, after years of effervescent gains, are going as flat as that unfinished bottle of champagne.
“Metro Denver real estate values have peaked and are falling in some locales,” said Van Lewis, a broker associate with Re/Max Alliance in Aurora.
Year-to-date through November, the median price of a home or condo sold in metro Denver is up 2.4%, according to the Denver Metro Association of Realtors.
Diminishing concerns about a recession are leading some forecasters to predict more robust home price gains in metro Denver and elsewhere.
CoreLogic forecasts its index of metro Denver home prices will rise 4% next year, an acceleration from the 3.4% gain measured through October.

title: Nursing homes with coronavirus outbreaks have citation, investigation history with state
summary:
AURORA, Colo —Two nursing homes with significant COVID-19 outbreaks have a history with the state for not doing enough to stop the spread of disease before the pandemic struck, and a third is being investigated by the state for similar conditions.
At least 33 people have died after being diagnosed with COVID-19 and at least 81 confirmed cases have been reported at these three nursing homes and assisted care facilities in Colorado.
RELATED: At least 47 dead from COVID-19 at nursing homes across ColoradoAs of April 5, there have been 47 confirmed deaths at all nursing homes and assisted care facilities in the state.
New numbers on nursing homes and assisted care facilities are expected to be released on Wednesday.
His advice has changed as the situation in nursing homes across the state develops.

title: Aurora police officer cited for suspected DUI after crashing into tree
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing

summary:
An Aurora police officer was cited early Tuesday morning for allegedly drunk driving and crashing into a tree in a Colorado Springs neighborhood.
Officer Jaired Dozier was injured in the crash and transported to a hospital, according to a Colorado Springs police blotter.
“He let us know he’s an Aurora officer,” Sokolik said.
The officer, Nate Meier, never faced criminal charges in the case because Aurora police never investigated the incident as a crime.
Another Aurora police officer, Annette Brook, pleaded guilty in January to DUI and was sentenced to home detention and probation.

title: Dozens of puppies being auctioned online by Aurora amid coronavirus
authors: Kieran Nicholson Covers Breaking News For The Denver Post. He Started At The Post In
California Streets. Nicholson Has Covered A Variety Of Beats Including Suburbs
summary:
Forty-four puppies are being auctioned online this week by the city of Aurora with no live, in-person viewing or bidding because of the coronavirus.
The animals were seized earlier this month from Pet City, in the Town Center at Aurora Mall, because of an outstanding tax bill of $86,000, according to an Aurora news release.
“The animals that were taken as part of this action were transferred to the Aurora Animal Shelter and partner agencies for evaluation and care,” the release said.
Coronavirus concerns led the city to use the online process to comply with social distancing and avoid crowds gathering to bid in person.
Coronavirus concerns also prohibit people from viewing the animals in person.

title: Opinion: GEO could be creating Colorado's most dangerous COVID-19 reservoir
authors: Dr. Kendyl Salcito Has A Phd In Epidemiology The Swiss Tropical
Public Health Institute In Basel Switzerland. She Serves As Executive Director Of Nomogaia
Is A Security Fellow With The Truman National Security Project.
Dr. Salcito Are Co-Directors Of Truman National Security Project S Colorado Chapter. Views Expressed Are Their Own.
Steven Leach Has Volunteered In Detention Facilities In South Africa
summary:
The state’s testing capacity is maxed out, but has entirely missed one population: detainees.
The GEO ICE Detention facility in Aurora is particularly ill-equipped to control COVID-19 spread.
Instead, cash bonds should be lowered or eliminated for ICE detainees and across all detention systems, from asylum seekers in ICE detention facilities to non-violent offenders at all levels.
It requires a new playbook, and decreasing the populations of all detention facilities should be at the top of the list.
Lowering or eliminating cash bonds for asylum seekers at the Aurora ICE facility is a small step in the right direction.

summary:

(Petrequin) Pautler.
In addition to his parents and first wife, he was preceded in death by two sisters Yvonne Basler and Elaine McCammon.
He and his first wife moved to Perryville when he purchased The Monitor weekly newspaper on April 1, 1964.
Memorials may be made to First Presbyterian Church of Cape Girardeau or charity of choice.

title: Police release suspect description in Aurora shooting at Buckley and Pagosa
summary:
AURORA, Colo. (KDVR) — Police are looking for a man suspected of critically wounding another in a shooting at South Buckley Way and South Pagosa Circle.
Police said the suspect is described as a white man in his 20s who drove a black SUV.
The man wounded in the shooting remained in critical condition as of Friday night, according to police.
According to the Aurora Police Department, the shooting occurred about 8:30 p.m. near the intersection of South Buckley Way and South Pagosa Way.
Police said they are working to gather information about a suspect.

title: These Are The Treatments And Cures Colorado Researchers Are Developing For Coronavirus
summary:
In Colorado, doctors and researchers are desperately looking for ways to treat patients with COVID-19.
Research into some drugs and treatments are farther along than others, and many show signs of promise.
Those treatments are some of the biggest breakthroughs in public health, but they require time and money.
For COVID-19 patients, receiving the plasma from someone who has recovered from the virus can help their body to fight off the disease.
The Food and Drug Administration released its guidelines for giving convalescent plasma to COVID-19 patients, and has encouraged researchers to begin clinical trials to investigate its efficacy.

title: Four people taken to hospitals after Monday morning shooting in Aurora
summary:
Aurora police are investigating a Monday morning shooting that sent four people to hospitals.
A fourth person at the scene was taken to a hospital for shortness of breath, likely from running from the scene, Longshore said.
“We are trying to piece together exactly what happened,” Longshore said.
The shooting happened at 10:50 a.m. outside an apartment complex on South Potomac Street and East 4th Avenue.
No arrests have been made, but police believe they know everyone involved, Longshore said.

title: Pete Buttigieg To Hold Aurora Town Hall As Colorado Starts To Capitalize On Super Tuesday
authors: Colorado Public Radio Staff The Associated Press
summary:
Now that Michael Bennet is out of the race for the White House, Colorado is suddenly catching the eye of presidential candidates.
It doesn't hurt that the state is part of Super Tuesday on March 3.
South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg, who won in Iowa and finished behind Bernie Sanders in New Hampshire, will host a town hall in Aurora on Feb. 22.
Unlike the last visit, which was a fundraiser, this event is free and open to the public.
It should also be noted that President Donald Trump's "Keep America Great" campaign will bring him to Colorado on Feb. 20 for a rally at the Broadmoor World Arena in Colorado Springs.

title: Man arrested, accused of critically wounding another man in Aurora shooting
summary:
AURORA, Colo. (KDVR) — The Aurora Police Department says a man has been arrested for allegedly critically wounding another man in a shooting Friday night.
Police said David Torrez, 33, was charged with two counts of attempted homicide for the shooting at South Buckley Way and South Pagosa Circle.
The man wounded in the shooting remained in critical condition as of Friday night, according to police.
The victim’s identity has not been released.

title: One person wounded from shooting at Aurora condominium
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoAURORA, Colo. — Aurora police are investigating a shooting that occurred at an Aurora condominium on Saturday morning that wounded a woman.
Police say a person shot into a condominium at about 5:50 a.m. in the 1700 block of South Pitkin Street.
The woman was transported to the hospital in stable condition.
The wounded woman was not alone inside the home when someone shot into the residence, but police did not immediately have information on how many others were present, according to an Aurora Police spokesperson.
#APDAlert Officers on scene of a shooting in the 1700blk of S. Pitkin St.

title: At Klobuchar’s Aurora Rally, Plenty Of Voters Who Are Interested, But Still Undecided
summary:
Democratic voter Michael Herrera of Denver is also concerned about a possible Sanders nomination.
Klobuchar has been on his radar ever since her high-profile exchange with U.S. Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh during his confirmation process.
Herrera said Klobuchar and South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg, who will be in Colorado for an event on Saturday, are his top choices.
Biden held a fundraiser earlier this week, and Sanders drew more than 11,000 to his rally last Sunday.
And in addition to Buttigieg, this weekend will also see a Warren rally on Sunday.

title: Aurora proclaims itself “Safest Large City in Colorado,” but is that true?
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania
The Chattanooga Times Free Press In Tennessee. She'S Been A Reporter Since
She Helped The Newspaper Earn The Pulitzer Prize For Breaking News After A Mass Shooting At A Local Synagogue.
summary:
The self-proclaimed “Safest Large City in Colorado” is holding on to its title by a thread — and perhaps shouldn’t claim the distinction at all, experts said.
Aurora has for several years billed itself as the safest city in Colorado with a population higher than 250,000 — a category that includes only Denver, Colorado Springs and Aurora — and backed the claim with crime rates calculated from data collected annually by the FBI.
“I still believe Aurora is the safest large city in the state,” Mayor Mike Coffman said Wednesday.
On Feb. 1, the department launched a 14-person task force to focus on identifying and targeting violent crime, Brown said.
He declined to discuss the “Safest Large City in Colorado” mantra, but public information Officer Matthew Longshore said the narrowed gap between the crime rates in Denver, Colorado Springs and Aurora may be attributed in part to Aurora’s rapid population growth.

title: Two teens remain hospitalized after Monday’s triple shooting in Aurora
summary:
Two people involved in an Aurora shooting Monday remain hospitalized in serious condition, and two more have been released from the hospital and charged with aggravated robbery.
One of those hospitalized is a 19-year-old man, who will be charged with attempted murder upon his release, the Aurora Police Department said in a Wednesday news release.
Aurora police responded to a 911 call Monday morning in the area of North Potomac Circle and East 4th Avenue, the news release said.
Officers located two other 19-year-old men, who had been running from the scene, near East 2nd Place and North Potomac Street.
Story updated at 12:23 p.m., Feb. 12, 2020: The charge a hospitalized 19-year-old faces in connection with the shooting has been corrected.

title: Killings among Denver’s teens continue, even as city and community leaders try new solutions
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
Eight teenagers were shot and killed in Denver last year, marking a second year of increased bloodshed among Denver’s young people.
City leaders held countless meetings to talk about solutions, and the mayor created a task force.
Easy solutions to the violence are hard to come by because the causes of the problem are varied and deeply rooted, city and community leaders said.
Aurora, too, is seeing an uptick in youth violence.
At a Denver City Council committee meeting last month, Denver City Attorney Kristin Bronson said the mayor’s task force on youth gun violence had an “aggressive work plan” for 2020.

title: Klobuchar to campaign in Aurora Thursday as 2020 candidates head to Colorado
summary:
DENVER – Six presidential candidates will campaign in Colorado in the three weeks ahead of the state’s Super Tuesday primary election, and with ballots already in voters’ hands.
Amy Klobuchar, the Democratic senator from Minnesota, is hosting an event on Thursday, Feb. 20, at 5 p.m. at the Stanley Marketplace in Aurora.
Bernie Sanders, the senator from Vermont, drew 11,000 people to his rally at the Colorado Convention Center in Denver on Sunday.
Pete Buttigieg, the former South Bend, Indiana mayor, will host a town hall in Aurora at 7 p.m. on Saturday, and Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic senator from Massachusetts, will host a campaign event Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Fillmore Auditorium in Denver.
President Trump is expected to win Colorado’s Republican primary but there have been no recent polls of the Democratic field in Colorado.

title: Aurora Police Department fires officer for 'severe misconduct,' but releases very few details
summary:
AURORA, Colo. – The Aurora interim police chief said Monday, in what she called an effort at transparency, that the department had fired an officer for what she called “severe misconduct” — but the department would only name the officer after repeated requests from multiple media outlets.
Officer Levi Huffine was fired Monday for an incident – which police did not describe – that happened in August 2019, a department spokesperson confirmed.
“I promised transparency to our residents to help build back the trust within our community,” Wilson wrote.
“I am unable to provide additional details or information about this incident until that process has been complete,” Wilson wrote.

title: Aurora couple first to go to prison in connection with large-scale Colorado black market marijuana ring
authors: Sam Tabachnik Is A Breaking News Reporter For The Denver Post
summary:
An Aurora couple was sentenced in federal court this week for their role in a large-scale black market marijuana grow operation, the first people to be sent to prison as part of a massive Denver-area drug take-down announced last year.
Huanyu Yan, 54, and You Lan Xiang, 50, received 36 months and 30 months in federal prison, respectively, for growing nearly 900 marijuana plants in their basement with plans to distribute the drug, the U.S. Attorney’s Office said in a news release.
The two were found guilty in December of marijuana cultivation following a four-day trial.
“These defendants turned their family home into a full-scale drug manufacturing facility,” U.S. Attorney Jason Dunn said in a statement.
The investigation, touted by law enforcement as the largest pot bust in Colorado history, netted dozens of arrests and the seizure of more than 80,000 marijuana plants and millions of dollars in cash.

summary:

He said that “senior people” made the decision to waive off that DUI officer and that his investigative team determined that the request came from a traffic commander or possibly even higher up.
Those rights protect a person from being compelled by the government to be a witness against themselves, and applies to the Fifth Amendment, but is focused on internal affairs investigations.
In a nutshell, prosecutors cannot use compelled evidence given up by the subject of an internal affairs investigation in a criminal investigation.
Wilson, in her response to Denver7 on Thursday, said that moving forward, in similar cases, the department will conduct a criminal investigation before an internal affairs investigation.

title: Nine injured in multi-car crash in Aurora
summary:
Nine people, including seven juveniles, were taken to a hospital after a Wednesday morning crash at 6th Avenue and Sable Boulevard in Aurora after the driver of a stolen pickup truck ran a red light.
One person suffered critical injuries, a second had serious injuries and seven others suffered minor injuries in the crash, according to an Aurora Police Department news release.
Four vehicles were involved, including an RTD bus and an Aurora city-owned truck, Aurora police spokeswoman Crystal McCoy said.
The driver of the RTD bus and the driver of the city’s truck were taken to the hospital.
A person in another pickup truck was not injured.

title: Lara Trump to hold rally in Aurora day before Colorado Springs Trump campaign event

AURORA, Colo. – Campaign adviser Lara Trump will hold a campaign event in Aurora on Feb. 19 – a day before another campaign rally featuring the president in Colorado Springs.
The event will be held on Wednesday, Feb. 19 at 6:30 p.m. at the Hyatt Regency Aurora-Denver, located at 13200 E 14th Place in Aurora.
According to a release from the campaign and Colorado GOP, the event is a “keep America Great” rally that “will highlight the accomplishments of the Administration and the commitments of the President.”The release says that senior campaign adviser Lara Trump, who is Eric Trump’s wife, will be at the event.
The president’s rally will happen less than two weeks before the March 3 Colorado primary on Super Tuesday.
Correction: This story has been corrected to show that the Aurora event is a Trump campaign event but that only Lara Trump will be there, not the president.

title: Now’s Your Chance To Tell RTD What You Think Of Its Plan For Service Cuts
summary:
Have thoughts on the Regional Transportation District's proposal to cut service later this year?
You'll have more than 15 opportunities to relay those thoughts to RTD in person at public meetings from Boulder to Parker — and most places in between.
These cuts were proposed last fall as RTD's last-ditch effort to give its overworked operators a break.
Six bus lines would be cut entirely, with reductions on 19 other bus routes and three light rail lines.

Neighbors also wonder who owns the home and who's been paying property taxes on it.
The city of Aurora tells the FOX31 Problem Solvers that it's conducted 16 abatements on the property over the past five years.

Sen. Klobuchar’s campaign said the candidate will be in 11 different states between now and Tuesday, when 16 states and territories hold primaries and caucuses.
The Denver rally is scheduled to be at Mile High Station at 1 p.m. on Monday.
Sen. Klobuchar told Colorado Matters earlier this week that a “Blue Wall extends to the West.”“I think the West has a lot to do with a victory, and that is, of course, Colorado,” she said.
A recent poll shows Sen. Klobuchar at 6 percent in Colorado and behind other Democratic candidates.

After Writing For Newspapers In Mesa
The Associated Press In Salt Lake City. Mitchell First Started Writing The Cold Case Blog In Fall
In Part Because Colorado Has More Than Unsolved Homicides.
summary:
Denver police arrested a 52-year-old woman for investigation of first-degree murder in the Sunday night shooting death of a man.
Police were called to the home at 8:10 p.m. by King, who reported the victim was dead and a gun was on the floor.
The victim had a single gunshot wound under an eye, and it did not appear to be a close contact wound, the affidavit said.
Police redacted the comments King made to police during their investigation at the home.
At police headquarters, King declined to talk to a detective, the arrest affidavit said.

summary:

Snow is also on the way for Saturday morning from Sunday through Tuesday, and possibly next Friday (February 21).

title: Elizabeth Warren To Visit Denver On Sunday, The Latest In A Week Of Presidential Campaign Visits
summary:
Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren is back on the campaign trail trying to reinvigorate her campaign after a disappointing finish in the New Hampshire primary.
She plans to be in Denver for a public event on Sunday, Feb. 23, at the Fillmore Auditorium.
But Warren made an early investment in Colorado, which her campaign now hopes will pay off.
Warren is the latest of several 2020 contenders announcing visits to Colorado ahead of Super Tuesday.
The man they are all competing to beat, President Donald Trump, is also due to be in Colorado this week.

title: Arvada police investigating fatal shooting of teenage boy
summary:
One teenager is dead and another is being held for investigation of manslaughter after a fatal shooting in Arvada.
Police responded Thursday afternoon to reports of a shooting on the 8100 block of Chase Drive.
They found a teenage boy with a gunshot wound, and he died on scene from his injuries, Arvada police Detective Dave Snelling said.
Two other teenage boys were at the scene and taken into custody.
All three of the boys knew each other, and the incident does not present a danger to the community, Snelling said.

title: Ambulance report suggests Aurora fire paramedic gave too much sedative to man who later died
summary:
The Aurora Fire Rescue medic “administered 500 mg Ketamine IM to (patient’s) R deltoid prior to discussing (patient’s) weight and proper dosage with Falck medic,” the report said.
In an effort to calm McClain after the altercation, an Aurora Fire Rescue lieutenant and an AFR medic suggested a 500mg dose of ketamine.
Because Aurora Fire Rescue does not currently carry the drug, a Falck Ambulance paramedic provided it.
There is no conclusive evidence that the care provided by Aurora Fire Rescue contributed to his death."
Cichuniec said he estimated McClain’s weight to be about 190 pounds.

Walsh found that nearly all of the lower-level officers involved in the incident acted appropriately.
The group of command staff who reviewed the internal affairs investigation recommended that Meier be fired.
Multiple officers in the department raised red flags internally that the incident needed more investigation.
The incident became public after a report by CBS4 in December, during the last weeks of former Chief Nick Metz’s tenure.
He was supposed to be replaced by O’Keefe while the city searched for a permanent chief, but O’Keefe retired instead, citing the Meier incident he became embroiled in.

title: One dead in wrong-way crash on Colfax in east Aurora
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — One person died in a wrong-way crash early Sunday on East Colfax Avenue, according to a news release from the Aurora Police Department.
Officers responded at 1:16 a.m. to a two-vehicle crash on Colfax between Laredo Street and Airport Boulevard, which is east of Interstate 225, according to the release.
A 1996 Cadillac had been driving west in the eastbound lanes of Colfax and crashed head-on with a Ford Explorer pickup.
Aurora Police say it's not known why the Cadillac was on the wrong side of Colfax.
They also did not say whether drugs or alcohol played a role in the crash.

title: Copper Mountain sees snowiest February ever with 88″ of powder
authors: John Meyer Is A Member Of The Colorado Ski
The Colorado Running Hall Of Fame.
summary:
860 SharesWith 10 inches of fresh snow to report Monday morning, Copper Mountain broke its record for February snowfall.
With six days left in the month, Copper has received 88 inches of snow.
Winter Park has had its third-snowiest February, with 86 inches.
The record for Winter Park is 122.3 inches in 1993, when it snowed every day of the month except Valentine’s Day.
Winter Park probably won’t get enough snow this week to break its record, but it’s less than 2 inches behind its second-snowiest month (1989).

title: Former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords to endorse Hickenlooper in Senate race, host Aurora rally
summary:
John Hickenlooper in the Democratic primary for Colorado’s Senate seat and the two will host a panel discussion on gun violence in Aurora early next month.
Giffords has been a leading voice against gun violence since she was shot at a political rally in Arizona in January 2011.
The rally and panel discussion with Hickenlooper and Giffords is scheduled for 5:30 p.m. on Monday, March 9 at the Heritage Christian Center in Aurora.
8 and the former congresswoman appeared with several of the state’s Democratic congressmen at a town hall on gun violence in Aurora.

title: Man charged with first-degree murder in Aurora shooting death on Colfax Avenue near a night club
authors: Kieran Nicholson Covers Breaking News For The Denver Post. He Started At The Post In
California Streets. Nicholson Has Covered A Variety Of Beats Including Suburbs
summary:
A suspect has been charged in the shooting death last month of a man on East Colfax Avenue in Aurora.
Alexander Albayero, 44, faces a first-degree murder charge in the Dec. 14 death of Juan Manuel Galindo Argumedo, according to an Adams County District Attorney’s Office news release.
The shooting happened near the Las Adelitas Night Club, 12249 E. Colfax Avenue.
Albayero, on Thursday, was advised of the charge against him in Adams District Court.
A preliminary hearing is scheduled onFeb. 14.

title: Aurora police warn of money order scam targeting teens
summary:
The Aurora Police Department’s Economic Crimes Unit began investigating a forgery scam in July 2019 that targeted high school students.
The suspects used social media to entice teens to provide their bank account information.
But the suspects used forged money orders and the victims lost thousands and are financially responsible for the lost money.
Anytime somebody wants to put a check into your account and have them send money or give them back money, it’s a scam.
Obviously don’t give your bank account, your PIN number away to anybody, if you trust them or not.

title: Man attacked elderly woman at knifepoint in Aurora, stole her car, police say
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — Police are searching for a man accused of attacking an elderly woman in Aurora and robbing her at knifepoint.
The attack happened about 2:20 p.m. on Feb. 18, near South Chambers Road and East Smoky Hill Road, according to a police news release Friday.
The suspect pulled out a knife, punched the woman and stole her vehicle, which was later found, police said.
Police described the suspect as a white man in his late 20s to early 30s and about 200 pounds.
Anonymous tipsters can contact Metro Denver Crime Stoppers at 720-913-STOP (7867) and be eligible for a reward of up to $2,000.

title: Sunday night shooting leaves one man dead in Aurora
summary:
Aurora police are investigating a homicide after a man was shot to death Sunday night.
Police responded to the 15600 block of East Caspian Circle on a report of “shots fired and then somebody on the ground” at 10:42 p.m., said police spokesman Officer Anthony Camacho.
Life saving measures were performed on the man but he died later at the hospital.
The Aurora Police Major Crimes/Homicide Unit will investigate the death.

She worked for Boeing during the war and at the Grays Harbor Chair Factory and a local seafood cannery after 1945 for a few years.
Helen lived in Aberdeen until 1977 with her husband, Joseph Jenna, (whom she married in 1946) and then moved to Montesano for the remainder of her life.
Helen was preceded in death by her parents, Adeline and Adam Paskas; brother, Joseph Paskas; husband, Joe; daughter, Karen Sawyer and son John David Morningside.

title: Executive function in women post-menopause
summary:
Researchers, including Dr. Neill Epperson of the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, remotely collected extensive cognitive data from women across the nation.
552 women who are BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutation carriers and have undergone RRSO completed the assessments, which measured executive function (a cognitive process that allows individuals to manage information in a planful versus reactive manner), exposure to early life stress, and mood symptoms.
Results show that adverse childhood experiences (ACE) were associated with more severe symptoms of executive dysfunction and worse performances on cognitive tasks post-surgical menopause.
Changes in mood, such as anxiety and depressive symptoms, partially mediated ACE associations on subjective and objective measures of executive function.
These findings indicate that assessing history of childhood adversity and current anxiety and depression symptoms may help to identify women who will experience executive cognitive complaints after surgical menopause.

summary:
Marijuana, which is still illegal at the federal level in the US, is now considered an “essential item.” Amid the coronavirus pandemic, marijuana has become essential in many US states.
Many states chose to make marijuana an essential item amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
Other states like Illinois, Florida, and Connecticut have also allowed marijuana as an essential item.
Cannabis stocks benefit tooWhile the coronavirus pandemic hit the global markets and economy, it benefited the cannabis industry.
To know more, read Coronavirus: Marijuana Industry Asks for Federal Business Relief.

title: Aurora, Colorado's most diverse city, is ready to distribute COVID-19 info to a community with 160 languages
summary:
Thanks to a program set up in 2017, the city has over 130 “Natural Helpers” ready to translate important messages and take them back to their communities.
According to Michael Bryant, a spokesman for the city of Aurora, there are about 160 languages spoken in Denver’s sister city.
Instead, Aurora’s Natural Helpers will likely translate and carry important messages from the Tri-County Health Department into their communities.
But Song said Natural Helpers can also cut through cultural barriers to make sure information is spread quickly.
“They do have the trust.”Song said there are over 130 Natural Helpers in Aurora who have graduated from eight cohorts, and another cohort is set to graduate on Saturday.

title: Metro School Districts Will Go On Extended Breaks Due To Coronavirus Concerns
summary:
Several of the state's largest school districts announced Thursday that they would institute extended closures of all schools as the coronavirus spreads through Colorado.
The Jeffco announcement capped a wild four hours of metro-area school district dominoes that mimicked the hours before a blizzard hits the area.
The Colorado school districts are following roughly the same pattern seen elsewhere in the nation as the coronavirus takes hold.
Mesa County, Summit and Douglas County school districts said there is a plan to provide meals to students who rely on them if those districts decided later to close.
Falcon School District 49, Poudre School Districts, Eagle County, Adams-12, Greeley-Evans School District 6 and Academy School District 20 said they do not have a plan but are actively looking for solutions should they choose to close.

summary:

And the governing body for the Colorado high school basketball tournaments, which begin final rounds Thursday, announced that attendance will be limited to essential team personnel.
As time goes on … we may see more recommendations for social distancing.”Here are some of the ways Coloradans have been adapting.
At Monarch High School in Louisville, the varsity baseball and men’s lacrosse teams called off spring break trips to Southern California to play against teams there, the Boulder Valley district office confirmed.
“I have decided to postpone this trip until the virus has settled down,” he told The Post this week.

title: Rare white mule deer seen around Denver metro area
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoAURORA, Colo. (KDVR) -- Colorado Parks and Wildlife confirms a rare mule deer has been spotted in Aurora.
There are reports of the deer being seen in other parts of the metro area as well.
Rhonda Erickson snapped pictures of the mule deer outside of her house along the Toll Gate Creek Trail, near East Mexico Avenue and South Buckley Road.
Rhonda Erickson captured these photos of a leucistic deer in Aurora.
“First one I’ve seen!”While the mule deer is indigenous to western North America, CPW says only about one in 30,000 are leucistic.

title: Aurora pet store closed, owner owes $86,000 in back taxes
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoAURORA, Colo. (KDVR) -- An Aurora pet store with a checkered past has been shut down by the city because of delinquent tax payments.
The Aurora Tax and Licensing Department confirms it shut down the “Pet City” pet store Tuesday.
The store is housed inside the Town Center at Aurora mall.
A city spokesman says the owner is responsible for $86,000 in back taxes.
“The animals were taken out of the pet shop,” said Trevor Vaughn, Aurora manager of Tax and Licensing.

title: Missing Aurora boy found safe, police say
summary:
AURORA, Colo. (KDVR) — Authorities were looking for a 10-year-old boy who had not been seen since he started walking home from his Aurora elementary school Thursday afternoon.
Police say the boy decided to walk home from Yale Elementary near East Yale Avenue and South Laredo Street about 2:55 p.m. Thursday.
“Today is the first day he didn’t ride the bus home,” the Colorado Bureau of Investigation said.
Shortly before 10 p.m., the Aurora Police Department said the boy had been found safe.
A citizen found him near East Mexico Avenue and South Chambers Road.

title: Killings among Denver’s teens continue, even as city and community leaders try new solutions
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
Eight teenagers were shot and killed in Denver last year, marking a second year of increased bloodshed among Denver’s young people.
City leaders held countless meetings to talk about solutions, and the mayor created a task force.
Easy solutions to the violence are hard to come by because the causes of the problem are varied and deeply rooted, city and community leaders said.
Aurora, too, is seeing an uptick in youth violence.
At a Denver City Council committee meeting last month, Denver City Attorney Kristin Bronson said the mayor’s task force on youth gun violence had an “aggressive work plan” for 2020.

title: Coronavirus Tests In Colorado: Who Gets Tested And How It Works
summary:
But who gets tested — and how it works — have caused a lot of confusion in Colorado and around the country.
Colorado now has the capacity to test for COVID-19, and the state health department says it can conduct up to 160 tests a day.
So far, the state has run far fewer tests than that each day.
“We have a limited number of tests,” said Jessica Bralish, communications director for the Colorado Department of Health and Environment.
In reality, the state has tested far fewer people than the number of tests reflect.

title: Colorado Districts Have Different Lesson Plans For Online Learning During Coronavirus Closures
summary:
The decisions reflect different philosophies, as well as access to resources, and have implications for longstanding academic gaps that plague many Colorado school districts.
When federal health officials asked school districts to plan for how they might continue educating students during an extended closure, most school districts felt unprepared.
Online learning could also be a challenge for young children, or students with special needs who rely on support services in schools.
School districts have a legal obligation, if they offer instruction at all, to serve all students.
Denver Public Schools is embarking on one of the longest closures in the state: three weeks, from March 16 through April 6.

title: Coronavirus vaccine in the works
summary:
This comes just days after President Donald Trump and other health officials visited the National Institutes of Health, where a vaccine is currently being developed.
"The president got to hear from the actual bench scientist who, within three days, developed a potential vaccine for the novel coronavirus," said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar.
Officials have said the coronavirus vaccine could potentially be available in as soon as a year.
"This is the first time we’re doing this for the coronavirus, so it’s going to take some dose findings...some range findings.
"That's where they see how effective the right dose of the vaccine is in helping people recover faster or helping prevent health care workers around them from being infected," Kroll said.

title: Aurora PD: Motorcyclist killed in crash near Quincy and Buckley
summary:
AURORA, Colo. (KDVR) — A motorcyclist was killed in a crash Tuesday afternoon in Aurora.
According to the Aurora Police Department, the crash was reported at 1:15 p.m.
It occurred at East Quincy Avenue and South Pitkin Street, which is just east of Quincy’s intersection with South Buckley Road.
According to APD, the sedan made a left turn in front of the motorcyclist.
The motorcycle hit the passenger side of the sedan and the motorcyclist was ejected.

title: Colorado license plate would honor theater shooting victims
summary:
AURORA (AP) — Campaigners for a new Colorado license plate option hope to honor victims of a theater shooting.
The campaign by nonprofit organization Aurora Rise needs 3,000 signatures to start the process of obtaining state approval for the license plate, The Aurora Sentinel reports.
The organization was established following the July 2012 mass shooting at a movie theater in Aurora.
The license plate would raise funds to benefit the state’s Victim Compensation Fund.
Additional funds from sales of the proposed license plate would benefit crime victims in the state needing assistance.

title: Denver shoppers snap up meat, veggies and pasta as grocers urge restraint
authors: Conrad Swanson Covers Denver Politics On The Denver Post S Political Team. An Iowa Native
He Joined The Paper In November After Stints At The Colorado Springs Gazette
Iowa . He Graduated The University Of Iowa With A Bachelor S Degree In Journalism
summary:
Despite the bleak appearances in produce and meat sections everywhere, food retail representatives urged restraint from customers.
Shelves will be restocked and supplies restored, said Chris Howes, president of the Colorado Retail Council.
The pasta and soup aisles sat empty, and dairy, bread, eggs, fresh meat and produce also ran low.
People raced inside as produce and meat sections dwindled and only blank spaces remained where cold and flu medicines once sat.
Shoppers should also be patient with employees, take care to clean shopping carts, and avoid sneezing or coughing on produce, he said.

One of the larger conferences, the American Society of Addiction Medicine is not canceling its annual conference in Denver.
“[Some] ticket holders requested refunds because they didn’t want to come to the show because of the coronavirus,” he said.
Rich Carollo, the director of sales at the Denver Convention Center, said many of his clients are concerned.
Kelly Brough, president and CEO of the Denver Metro Chamber of Commerce, said employers are actively looking at how to reduce the spread.

summary:

“Notably, at each stage of APD’s response, APD members themselves raised concerns about the appropriateness and adequacy of APD’s response."

After the incident, APD revised its policies to include this.
Referral to outside law enforcement agencies in cases where APD members are suspected of serious criminal misconduct.

title: Now’s Your Chance To Tell RTD What You Think Of Its Plan For Service Cuts
summary:
Have thoughts on the Regional Transportation District's proposal to cut service later this year?
You'll have more than 15 opportunities to relay those thoughts to RTD in person at public meetings from Boulder to Parker — and most places in between.
These cuts were proposed last fall as RTD's last-ditch effort to give its overworked operators a break.
Six bus lines would be cut entirely, with reductions on 19 other bus routes and three light rail lines.
The RTD board will likely vote on the plan in March.

title: First snow of the season leads to more than 300 crashes in Denver and Aurora
summary:

Heading into PM rush hour, we’ve received 193 traffic crash reports since 6AM.
Take your time out there, allow for extra stopping distance and just drive safely — we’d hate to have to delay your trip home...😉 #CommuteResponsibly #snow pic.twitter.com/wbZMRgabDp — Denver Police Dept.
In the past 3 hours, we’ve had 96 traffic crash reports.
(@DenverPolice) October 10, 2019The most common plea from the Denver Police Department, and other officials, was to slow down.

title: Bundle Up, Colorado. The Snow Is Mostly Over, Now It’s Time For The Cold
summary:
The previous record was a toasty 25 degrees set in 1993.
"We actually set a new record low this morning at Denver International Airport," Hanson said.
"We went down to 3 degrees — the previous record was 7 degrees."

title: Denver Post listening tour: Aurora, home to powerful institutions, wants to harness its diversity
authors: Denver Post Reporter John Aguilar Covers Hot-Button Issues Such As Oil
Transportation As They Play Out In The Denver Suburbs. He Joined The Post In After Previous Work At The Boulder Daily Camera
The Boulder County Business Report. He Hails Boston
summary:
The view from Aurora, though, is that it’s taking a while for the rest of metro Denver to grasp the change.
In Aurora, a common refrain is the city embraces its diversity but hasn’t fully harnessed it.
The base has “a very close partnership with the Aurora community,” Pepper said.
Carolyn Boller, a longtime Aurora resident who chairs the city’s election commission, responded defiantly when asked to size up her city vis-à-vis Denver.
“Their first response is, ‘Where is that in relation to Denver?’ I say, ‘Denver is a suburb of Aurora.

title: Man injured in Thursday night officer-involved shooting in Aurora
summary:
This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated.
AURORA, Colo. — A man was injured Thursday night in an officer-involved shooting in Aurora.
According to a news release from the Aurora Police Department, around 11:30 p.m., officers responded to the 1500 block of South Bahama Street on the report of an assault when they encountered an armed man.
Officials are asking anyone who was a witness to the shooting to contact Jamie Krieger at 303-739-6113.
Editor’s Note: An earlier version of this story said South Bahama “Circle” instead of “Street,” per information from APD.

title: Is Coronavirus the Knockout Punch for WeWork?
summary:
Now there’s increasing fear among some that WeWork could go dark, leaving scores of empty office space in its wake.
“In this pandemic, a business model like WeWork is in deep shit already,” said Alexander Snyder, an analyst at CenterSquare Investment Management who’s been following WeWork closely.
“I think people are right to ask the question, ‘What if WeWork and other coworking companies go down because of the economic impact of COVID-19?’”And the company is already showing some signs of strain.
If all the coworking space went back on the market, it would increase Class-A availability rates by 48 percent from its current 11.6 percent to 17.2 percent.
“It will be a disaster for New York landlords,” Poleg said.

title: 3 young girls found safe after running away from Aurora home
summary:
This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated.
AURORA, Colo.– Three young girls were found safe after running away from a home in Aurora following a family dispute Sunday night.
At around 10:20 a.m. on Monday, police said the girls were located and safe.
Police say Leanne, 13, Ashlyn, 9 and Serenity, 6, ran away from a home near East 19th Avenue and Jamaica Street around 7:30 p.m Sunday.
The young girls are cousins, according to police.

title: Aurora police released a portion of body camera footage from officer shooting outside apartment complex
summary:
Aurora police released a portion of body camera footage from an Oct. 20 shooting provides audio of a woman screaming “A guy has a big ass gun in his hands,” in the moments before an officer fires at a man.
The 45-second clip was released Monday morning along with commentary from deputy Chief Paul O’Keefe, who says the man was armed when an officer fired.
The officer tells the women to get back and then yells “drop the gun” twice before firing at the suspect.
O’Keefe said the suspect ignored the order to drop the weapon and turned toward the officer with the gun in his hands.The officer fired and the suspect jumped into an apartment window.
Police released only a small portion of the body-worn camera footage from the primary officer after he first arrives on scene.

title: Police take person into custody in Aurora, lift shelter in place and school bus route suspension
authors: Saja Hindi Is A Politics Reporter For The Denver Post. She'S An Award-Winning Reporter Who Has Previously Worked At The Fort Collins Coloradoan
The Loveland Reporter-Herald After Starting Her Journalism Career In North Carolina. She'S Covered Breaking News
summary:
School buses stopped and residents sheltered in place for about an hour Monday afternoon in the area of Heather Ridge Apartments in Aurora after someone may have fired a weapon in the air, according to Aurora police.
Police said they took someone into custody at about 4:50 p.m. and expected roads would reopen and the shelter in place lifted shortly after, according to an Aurora police tweet.
All Cherry Creek School District bus routes suspended driving to stops near the 2300 block of South Vaughn Way until the situation was resolved.
Entrances to the apartment complex from East Iliff Avenue and South Vaughn Way were closed, police said.
pic.twitter.com/foYMH66Dst — Aurora Police Dept (@AuroraPD) October 7, 2019Officers were trying to negotiate with a person inside an apartment to come out and surrender, according to Aurora police.

Haley had some personal friends at Westfield Co. that made getting the Stanley Marketplace project going that much easier.
Puri said one of the vendors inside Stanley Marketplace will be carrying Gotham Greens products as soon as they are ready to sell.
Aurora Mayor Bob LeGare especially likes that part of Gotham Green’s plans for his city.
He characterized the area around Stanley Marketplace as a food desert that could benefit from more fresh produce being made available on store shelves.

title: A unarmed man died in Aurora police custody. His family is calling for criminal prosecution of officers.
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
The family of a man who died after a violent arrest by Aurora police called Tuesday for criminal prosecution of the officers involved.
McClain’s family and friends, religious leaders and community members gathered outside the building holding signs stating “He did no wrong” and “Justice for Elijah McClain!”“What happened was an absolute atrocity,” Newman said.
McClain’s family and Newman last week watched footage from the officers’ body camera and heard the original 911 call at the invitation of Aurora police.
Three officers approached McClain Aug. 24 after receiving a call about a suspicious person wearing a ski mask and waving his arms.
Reginald Holmes, a Denver pastor, and McClain’s family called for criminal prosecutions of the officers involved and said a monetary compensation alone would not be adequate.

On Friday she was driving with her friends, and they got into a road rage incident with three other women near the intersection of Quincy and Buckley in Aurora.
“I looked at her, and I spit right at her.”Then she started recording a video on her phone.
In the video, the BMW driver drove into the back of Ruellas’ car, and then drove away.
Even though a couple of drivers chased the BMW, and Ruellas captured the license plate.

title: Denver weather: Accumulating snow looking more likely on Thursday
authors: Science For The Denver Post. He Has His Certification In Broadcast Meteorology Mississippi State University
He Also Holds A Broadcasters' Seal Of Approval The National Weather Association. He Works Full-Time As A Broadcast Meteorologist At Weathernation
A National Weather Network Headquartered In Centennial.
summary:
Most of the snow in the Denver area, however, will likely mainly stick to colder surfaces, particularly if it falls during the daytime hours on Thursday.
#COwx pic.twitter.com/uCto7zELdd — Chris Bianchi (@BianchiWeather) October 6, 2019On Sunday night, the National Weather Service office in Boulder included a chance for snow showers in their Thursday forecast for Denver.
The precipitation may start as rain initially on Wednesday night, before a changeover to snow Wednesday night into Thursday morning.
“If a hard freeze is not reached Wednesday night, it most certainly will be met by Thursday night,” the National Weather Service in Boulder wrote on Sunday night’s forecast discussion.
In addition, accumulating snowfall could impact Thursday’s morning and evening commutes, although at this time it appears road impacts from snow should be fairly limited.

title: 23-year-old man suspected in fatal hit-and-run crash with pedestrian in Aurora is arrested
authors: Kieran Nicholson Covers Breaking News For The Denver Post. He Started At The Post In
California Streets. Nicholson Has Covered A Variety Of Beats Including Suburbs
summary:
A suspect in a fatal hit-and-run crash in Aurora has been arrested, police said.
Jackson Donald, 23, of Aurora, has been arrested on suspicion of accidents involving death or personal injuries, according to police.
At about 6:40 a.m. Saturday, a woman was hit and killed by a vehicle as she crossed East Iliff Avenue near Interstate 225, according to police.
Based on witness information, investigators were looking for a black, late-model Nissan Altima and they found a possible suspect vehicle registered to a driver at an apartment complex not far from the crash, police said.
Police said on Monday that Donald is being held on the felony charge in the case.

title: Aurora police locate suspect in fatal hit-and-run
authors: Sam Tabachnik Is A Breaking News Reporter For The Denver Post
summary:
Aurora police are investigating a fatal hit-and-run that occurred Saturday morning.
A woman was crossing the road to contact the other driver after being involved in a two-car crash when she was hit, police said.
The woman was transported to a hospital, where she died as a result of her injuries, police said.
The vehicle’s driver-side bumper will be missing and damaged, and the driver’s side mirror also is missing, police said.
Anyone with information is encouraged to call Aurora Police Traffic Investigations at 303-739-6243.

title: Torture, Murder Claimed in Elijah McClain Aurora Police Death
summary:
Officers arrived in the area and contacted a male still wearing a ski mask, later identified as Elijah McClain.

Elijah McClain "was a man who was never once arrested in his entire life," she continued.
Attorney Mari Newman spoke alongside Elijah McClain's family members and representatives of the Greater Metro Denver Ministerial Alliance, among others.
We are demanding not just compensatory justice, but we are calling for prosecutorial justice for the McClain family.

title: Man arrested on suspicion of DUI, leaving crash that left 1 dead in Aurora
authors: Saja Hindi Is A Politics Reporter For The Denver Post. She'S An Award-Winning Reporter Who Has Previously Worked At The Fort Collins Coloradoan
The Loveland Reporter-Herald After Starting Her Journalism Career In North Carolina. She'S Covered Breaking News
summary:
A 26-year-old man has been arrested in connection to a crash that left one person dead early Sunday morning, according to Aurora police.
Cameron Smith was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence and leaving the scene of an accident involving death, police said in a release.
Smith was driving a Ford SUV northbound on Interstate 225 and getting off at East Mississippi Avenue when he drove into the intersection and crashed into a Lexus SUV that was headed eastbound, police said.
The suspect walked away from the crash, but some people told police he was at a nearby business where officers found and arrested him.
Smith is being held at the Arapahoe County Jail on a $10,000 bond, and he is scheduled to be in court at 8:30 a.m. Thursday, according to jail records.

title: Surprise, Colorado! The Snow Got Here Early And A Lot More Will Still Fall Through Wednesday
summary:
--Remember Monday's morning commute?
Snowstorms rarely care for forecasts, and a band of snow unexpectedly dropped in on Denver this morning, snarling the commute.
The National Weather Service still thinks the snow will pick up for a "solid 8 inches or so here in the Denver metro area."
Heavier snow will still develop later and disrupt the afternoon commute for the Front Range.
Bottom line advice: If you braved the snow for the morning commute, leave early to beat the brunt of the storm later today — and start to think about what you'll do for Wednesday morning.

title: Aurora warns water customers about data breach involving payment system
summary:
AURORA — The city of Aurora is warning water customers about a data breach involving one of their payment systems.
They say customers who used the ‘Click2Gov’ system to submit one-time or to setup recurring payments between around August 30th – October 14th of 2019 may be affected.
“Aurora Water is committed to protecting the security of our customers’ information and the integrity of our payment systems is of the highest importance.
The city says the investigation is ongoing and they’ve setup a dedicated website where more information will be posted.
Aurora is currently in the process of switching to a different online payment system which they say was not affected by this incident.

title: Aurora police say man they shot through window of house knew police were outside; family calls police statement a lie
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing

summary:
An Aurora police deputy chief confirmed Friday that officers did not announce themselves as police in the moments before they shot an armed man through front window of his home.
Still, deputy chief Paul O’Keefe insisted during a Friday news conference the man, Andrew Huff, knew they were cops when he grabbed a gun.
Aurora police on Friday were able to clarify that the bullet that struck the unnamed man in the Oct. 20 shooting was fired by an Aurora police officer.
O’Keefe also clarified that officers who responded to Huff’s home Oct. 10 did not announce themselves as Aurora police officers before firing at Huff through the window.
Huff’s parents told reporters after the police news conference that their son would never grab a gun if he knew police were outside, especially because Huff’s wife and young daughter were in the home.

summary:

Their sister told police that Lee Fabricius drinks a lot and struggles with depression, the arrest affidavit states.
At 9:30 on the night of the crash, Dale Fabricius had texted his brother, asking him to go to a safe house.
“You are so wasted tonight you didn’t even recognize me,” Dale Fabricius wrote to his brother.
In addition to first-degree murder, Lee Fabricius was charged with vehicular homicide, driving under the influence of alcohol and careless driving resulting in death.

title: Denver could set its coldest October temperature on record this week
authors: Science For The Denver Post. He Has His Certification In Broadcast Meteorology Mississippi State University
He Also Holds A Broadcasters' Seal Of Approval The National Weather Association. He Works Full-Time As A Broadcast Meteorologist At Weathernation
A National Weather Network Headquartered In Centennial.
summary:
Denver could come close to, if not potentially set its coldest October temperature on record this week as two waves of Arctic air blast through the region.
Denver’s current coldest October temperature on record is a -2 degree reading back on Oct. 29, 1917.
The National Weather Service’s current forecast projects a low temperature of just 1 degree on Wednesday night, which would place it just behind the 1917 reading for the coldest October temperature title.
If Wednesday night’s temperature drops down to 1 degree, it would still make it Denver’s coldest October temperature in more than 100 years.
Daily record lows are possible on both Wednesday and Thursday, meaning Denver could well be looking at its coldest Halloween on record.

title: Halloween Storm to Bring Snow to Central Plains, Midwest (PHOTOS)
summary:
(Andy Cross/MediaNews Group/The Denver Post via Getty Images)A winter storm is moving into the Plains and Midwest Wednesday after dumping several inches of snow on the Rockies earlier this week.
More than six inches of snow fell in Denver , causing traffic jams along Interstate 25 and road closures on Interstate 70 in Aurora, Colorado.
The storm, which the Weather Channel has named Winter Storm Bessie, was the second storm in two days to strike the Rockies.
The National Weather Service has issued winter storm warnings and winter weather advisories from the central Rockies and parts of the Central and Southern Plains and eastward into a narrow strip of the mid-Mississippi Valley and northern Illinois.
The Central Plains and parts of the Midwest could see a snowy Halloween as the storm moves eastward, bringing light to moderate snowfall.

title: Denver’s biggest October snowstorms
authors: Science For The Denver Post. He Has His Certification In Broadcast Meteorology Mississippi State University

summary:
But, each of the last two Octobers have featured notable early season snow events.
With all of that in mind, here are Denver’s top October snowstorms on record:Oct. 24-25, 1923: A foot of snow fell on Denver — mere hours after it had reached 70 degrees.
Oct. 3-5, 1969: Denver’s snowiest October on record featured 16 inches of snow in the opening week of the month.
Up to 31 inches fell in Aurora, and more than 50 inches fell on Coal Creek Canyon.
Oct. 20-23, 1906: Denver’s biggest October blizzard brought down newspaper cables, thanks to 22.7 inches of snow in just four days.

title: Aurora Teen Recalls Traumatizing Triple Shooting At Mission Viejo Park: ‘Hiding Behind A Car’
summary:
– Aurora police are still searching for the person who shot three people at random on Oct. 19 in Mission Viejo Park.
While the victims are no longer in the hospital, for one of the teenage victims, the shooting has taken a serious mental toll.
Jade was at the park, waiting with a friend outside his car when they noticed a tan SUV driving erratically.
“I was like hiding behind the car because I was scared he was going to shoot us again,” she said.
Angie never imagined her daughter would be at risk of being shot in their neighborhood park.

“However, ketamine may be associated with high in-hospital intubation and ICU admission rates; therefore the use of ketamine should be approached with caution.
“The video shows the opposite of anybody showing any signs of excited delirium,” Newman, said.
They have not confirmed that they used ketamine on McClain, though Aurora police have said the agency’s paramedics used a sedative.
Denver paramedics for years have used ketamine in the field if the patient is an imminent threat to a provider or themselves.
But sometimes they are.”Between August 2017 and July 2018, 427 patients in Colorado received ketamine for agitation, according to state data.

title: Denver weather: Snow ends, but record-cold October temperature possible tonight
authors: Science For The Denver Post. He Has His Certification In Broadcast Meteorology Mississippi State University
He Also Holds A Broadcasters' Seal Of Approval The National Weather Association. He Works Full-Time As A Broadcast Meteorologist At Weathernation
A National Weather Network Headquartered In Centennial.
summary:
It’s going to be exceptionally cold in Denver and along the Front Range Wednesday night into Thursday morning.
Denver International Airport reported 6.6 inches of snowfall on Tuesday, officially making it Denver’s largest one-day October snowfall since 2011.
As of early Wednesday morning, Denver International Airport had reported snow for 55 of the previous 71 hours of hourly weather observations.
The National Weather Service is calling for a low of -1 degrees at Denver International Airport on Wednesday night and into Thursday morning.
If tonight’s low temperature drops to 2 degrees or below, though, it would still be Denver’s coldest October temperature in over 100 years.

title: UNLIKELY SUSPECT: Those who knew Elijah balk at Aurora police account of his death
summary:
Some of McClain’s family and friends have little hope that the investigation will hold the involved officers accountable.
Regardless, McClain’s friends and family say they will never understand how a lifeso rich in positivity, spirituality and earnestness could end so violently at the hands of police.
“He wanted to change the world,” said Sheneen McClain, his mother.
“And it’s crazy, because he ended up doing it anyway.”Elijiah McClain was a Denver native, living in Aurora near his family.
She’s representing the McClain family.

title: Northern Lights Possible This Weekend In Colorado
summary:
If you've been looking for some pure delight after a week of heavy news headlines, you may get your chance this weekend with the potential that one of nature's most enchanting shows, the northern lights, may be visible in Colorado.
The Space Weather Prediction Center will continue to update its forecast through the weekend.
The science behind the northern lights is a bit complicated — all you really need to know is that they are jaw-dropping beautiful.
Here's a helpful map from the Space Weather Prediction Center to help you determine your chances of seeing the Aurora Borealis this weekend.
The higher the number assigned to it, the greater your chances are to see the northern lights.

title: Aurora police chief leaving position on his own terms, but won’t completely rule out a return to policing
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
Outgoing Aurora Police Chief Nick Metz knows too well the toll years of law enforcement work can exact on a person.
As Aurora’s first African American police chief, Metz has weathered many high profile controversies and attempted to forge relationships between his agency and the diverse city it’s charged with policing.
“It was truly a pleasure to work with Chief Metz,” said Judy Lutkin, president of the Aurora Police Association.
In his retirement, Metz plans to work for his wife, Sara Metz, at Code-4 Counseling.
He hopes the next chief will maintain the work he’s done with wellness and will further improve the department.

title: Election 2019: Aurora Mayoral Race Outcome Uncertain As Officials Sort Through Signature Discrepancies
summary:
AURORA, Colo. (CBS4) – Aurora's race for mayor could come down to several hundred ballots with signature discrepancies.
Results posted Thursday afternoon on the Colorado Secretary of State website show former U.S. Rep. Mike Coffman with 26,201 votes and Omar Montgomery with 25,928 votes.
Coffman's 273 vote lead is above the threshold for an automatic recount, but that could change.
Coffman's campaign told CBS4 there are approximately 550 Aurora ballots in Arapahoe County and 100 Aurora ballots in Adams County with signature discrepancies.
The clerk's offices in both counties have until Wednesday at noon to cure those ballots, which could affect the outcome of the race.

title: No. 4 Grandview downs No. 7 Eaglecrest in Centennial League slugfest
summary:

Heber booted a 39-yard field goal, cutting the Grandview lead to 7-3 early in the third quarter.
Eaglecrest looked to make it a one-possession game early in the fourth quarter, but another field goal attempt from Heber was blocked.
“But we’ll see (Eaglecrest) again in the playoffs.”The Wolves and Raptors will continue with conference matchups ahead.

title: ICE facility must notify Aurora of contagious disease outbreaks, City Council decides
authors: Denver Post Reporter John Aguilar Covers Hot-Button Issues Such As Oil

The Boulder County Business Report. He Hails Boston
Has A Master'S Degree The University Of Colorado At Boulder
summary:
Amid a raucous meeting that attracted a group of vocal immigrant rights advocates to city hall, Aurora City Council voted Monday to require that all detention facilities in Aurora notify the fire department in the event of a contagious disease outbreak.
“Recent contagious disease outbreaks at a local detention facility could potentially put first responders at risk,” city staff told council members in a memo attached to Monday night’s council packet.
Protesters demanded that Aurora become a sanctuary city and refrain from helping ICE agents capture or detain people who are in the country illegally.
After breaking out in a group chant, the group was escorted out of the council chambers by police.
In a tweet posted Tuesday morning, Frazier said people should be free to have their voices heard “but shutting down a council meeting is a step too far.”

title: Man charged with DUI in fatal Aurora hit-and-run crash
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — A man has been arrested and charged following a hit-and-run crash that left one person dead and another seriously injured in Aurora on Sunday.
Cameron Smith, 26, is charged with driving under the influence and leaving the scene of an accident involving death, according to the Aurora Police Department.
Police say the crash happened about 1:20 a.m. Sunday when Smith was driving a Ford SUV and was exiting northbound Interstate 225 at East Mississippi Avenue.
“Smith drove into the intersection and crashed broadside into a Lexus SUV that was driving eastbound.
The driver of the Lexus was killed and the passenger was seriously injured,” APD said in a press release.

title: Aurora Public Schools says new charter school is 'in breach of contract' related to low enrollment
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — One of Aurora's newest charter schools could face the loss of its charter if it doesn't come up with a solid financial viability plan this week.
Aurora Public Schools notified the Aurora Community School, on Oct. 3, that it was in breach of its contract regarding viability, based on under-enrollment.
The charter school, which meets at Restoration Christian Fellowship Church near E. 6th Avenue and Chambers Road, is closed this week for fall break.
In a statement to Denver7, a spokeswoman said, “Aurora Community School has demonstrated that our innovative 'community school' model is a strong fit for students in Aurora.
"Several staff members packed up their lives to come and work at Aurora Community School," the person said.

title: Campaign for Aurora mayor continues a week after Election Day
authors: Saja Hindi Is A Politics Reporter For The Denver Post. She'S An Award-Winning Reporter Who Has Previously Worked At The Fort Collins Coloradoan
The Loveland Reporter-Herald After Starting Her Journalism Career In North Carolina. She'S Covered Breaking News
summary:
Aurora voter Jesse Griffin didn’t think twice about the ballot she had submitted in this year’s election until a volunteer for Aurora mayoral candidate Omar Montgomery showed up at her door this week.
Volunteers for at least one candidate for Aurora mayor are still out talking to voters a week after Election Day, when other races across Colorado have long since been called.
So Montgomery volunteers started knocking on doors again, trying to cure, or correct, signature and identification discrepancies, on hundreds of ballots that weren’t counted.
As Montgomery walked around the office Tuesday afternoon talking to volunteers, he said he didn’t expect this kind of action.
To win the race, Montgomery estimates that his campaign needs 300 to 400 ballots cured, though he acknowledged the numbers could change.

title: Former Rep. Mike Coffman wins tight Aurora mayor’s race
authors: Denver Post Reporter John Aguilar Covers Hot-Button Issues Such As Oil

summary:
Former U.S. Rep. Mike Coffman declared victory as mayor of Aurora on the steps of City Hall on Thursday afternoon — nine days after Election Day — while calling for an investigation into the errors and delays in the electoral process.
Montgomery’s campaign said the candidate is waiting for all votes to be finalized and will make a statement Friday.
Going into last weekend, the three counties still had hundreds of Aurora ballots with signature and identification discrepancies to be cured, or corrected, so neither campaign would declare victory or concede defeat.
On Thursday, Coffman criticized the lengthy vote count and printing errors that occurred in Arapahoe and Adams counties.
The race became a nearly $1.2 million undertaking — and that’s just the dollars raised and reported by the candidates.

title: One person wounded in Aurora shooting; 2 suspects in custody
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoAURORA, Colo. -- The Aurora Police Department is investigating a shooting in which one person was wounded.
Two suspects are in custody.
About 4 p.m. Thursday, APD said the shooting occurred near the intersection of South Memphis Street and Pheasant Run Parkway.
The neighborhood is northwest of the intersection of East Smoky Hill Road and South Buckley Road.
A friend of the victim says he is a student at Smoky Hill High School.

title: Police: No evidence of shots fired outside of Town Center at Aurora mall
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — Aurora Police responded to a shots fired call outside of Town Center at Aurora Saturday night but never found any evidence of a firearm that was used.
“We haven’t located any evidence that anything happened,” said Aurora Police Public Information Officer Matt Longshore.
Video circulating on social media outlets shows people running out of the mall.
Officers are expected to remain on scene until the mall closes.
Anyone with any additional information is encouraged to contact Aurora’s dispatch center at (303)627-3100.

title: Aurora’s Mayoral Race Could Finally Be Settled Thursday
summary:
More than a week after Election Day, the final count of votes in Aurora’s mayoral race will be on Thursday.
“I think it’s safe to go off the numbers that are published tomorrow,” said Steve Ruger, Aurora’s city clerk.
According to state law, all counties have to be done counting ballots and release official results by Nov. 27.
“Nothing is official until the canvassing board for each county signs off on the official results,” he said.
The race between former Congressman Mike Coffman and Aurora NAACP president Omar Montgomery is still extremely close.

title: Police investigate triple-shooting in Aurora
summary:
AURORA– The Aurora Police Department is investigating a triple-shooting that happened early Monday morning.
Police were called to the area of South Ironton Street and Alameda Avenue around 2:20 a.m.
When they arrived on scene, they found two victims suffering from gunshot wounds.
The two victims were taken to the hospital in serious condition.
A third victim went to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries.

title: Election 2019: Aurora Mayoral Race Outcome Uncertain As Officials Sort Through Signature Discrepancies
summary:
AURORA, Colo. (CBS4) – Aurora's race for mayor could come down to several hundred ballots with signature discrepancies.
Results posted Thursday afternoon on the Colorado Secretary of State website show former U.S. Rep. Mike Coffman with 26,201 votes and Omar Montgomery with 25,928 votes.
Coffman's 273 vote lead is above the threshold for an automatic recount, but that could change.
Coffman's campaign told CBS4 there are approximately 550 Aurora ballots in Arapahoe County and 100 Aurora ballots in Adams County with signature discrepancies.
The clerk's offices in both counties have until Wednesday at noon to cure those ballots, which could affect the outcome of the race.

He was taken to a hospital and died at about 6 a.m. Police are investigating the incident as a homicide.
Anyone with information on the case is asked to call Aurora police at 303-739-6090.

title: Person fatally shot at Aurora’s Town Center mall, police say it’s “not a mass-shooter situation”
authors: Sam Tabachnik Is A Breaking News Reporter For The Denver Post
