He Joined The Paper In November After Stints At The Colorado Springs Gazette
summary:
Police were investigating the shooting death of a person inside the JCPenny store at the Town Center at Aurora mall about 4 p.m. Friday, police spokesman Anthony Camacho said.
Nobody has been arrested, and no identifying information for any possible suspects — or for the victim — was immediately available, Camacho said.
“We don’t have someone running through the mall shooting.”Camacho could not say how many people were involved in the shooting but that a handgun had been used.
The shots were fired near the middle of the JCPenney department store, Camacho said.
The department later wrote on Twitter that the shooting was being investigated as a homicide, indicating the victim’s death.

title: Aurora proclaims itself “Safest Large City in Colorado,” but is that true?
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania
The Chattanooga Times Free Press In Tennessee. She'S Been A Reporter Since
She Helped The Newspaper Earn The Pulitzer Prize For Breaking News After A Mass Shooting At A Local Synagogue.
summary:
The self-proclaimed “Safest Large City in Colorado” is holding on to its title by a thread — and perhaps shouldn’t claim the distinction at all, experts said.
Aurora has for several years billed itself as the safest city in Colorado with a population higher than 250,000 — a category that includes only Denver, Colorado Springs and Aurora — and backed the claim with crime rates calculated from data collected annually by the FBI.
“I still believe Aurora is the safest large city in the state,” Mayor Mike Coffman said Wednesday.
On Feb. 1, the department launched a 14-person task force to focus on identifying and targeting violent crime, Brown said.
He declined to discuss the “Safest Large City in Colorado” mantra, but public information Officer Matthew Longshore said the narrowed gap between the crime rates in Denver, Colorado Springs and Aurora may be attributed in part to Aurora’s rapid population growth.

title: Pedestrian walking in crosswalk killed after being hit by driver in Aurora
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — A pedestrian walking in a crosswalk was killed after being hit by a driver on Thursday afternoon, the Aurora Police Department said.
The crash happened at East Colfax Avenue and North Havana Street about 12:20 p.m.
Police said it appears the man was walking on the west side of Havana Street in a crosswalk when he was hit by a vehicle going northbound while making a left turn onto westbound Colfax Avenue.
The driver remained at the scene of the accident and is cooperating with the investigation, police said.
Southbound Havana Street was closed at Colfax Avenue and westbound Colfax Avenue was closed at Havana Street.

The incident began around 8:54 p.m. when police in northeast Denver began pursuing an armed robbery suspect, according to a statement from the Aurora Police Department.
Denver police used a helicopter to track the suspect’s vehicle, Denver Police Deputy Chief Barb Archer told reporters at the scene Saturday.
The pursuit went into Aurora and the suspect’s vehicle crashed into two cars on Interstate 225 and on East Colfax Avenue, according to Aurora police.
“During this final encounter with the suspect a Denver police officer made the decision to discharge their weapon striking the suspect,” Aurora police spokeswoman Crystal McCoy said in the statement.

summary:
Eight teenagers were shot and killed in Denver last year, marking a second year of increased bloodshed among Denver’s young people.
City leaders held countless meetings to talk about solutions, and the mayor created a task force.
Easy solutions to the violence are hard to come by because the causes of the problem are varied and deeply rooted, city and community leaders said.
Aurora, too, is seeing an uptick in youth violence.

title: Aurora man accused of trying to lure 13-year-old boy to home for 'sexual encounters'
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — An Aurora man has been arrested after allegedly trying to lure a 13-year-old boy he met online to his home.
In November 2019, police detectives with the Aurora Police Department’s Internet Crimes Against Children Unit started an investigation after learning a 13-year-old boy had met an adult online and was starting to get lured to the man’s residence "for sexual encounters," according to police.
The man, later identified as Andrew Sandoval, attempted to get the boy to visit his home on multiple occasions, police said.
He was then arrested for sexual assault on a child in a pattern of abuse, internet luring of a child, and sexual exploitation of a child.

title: Citizenship voting measure makes Colorado’s 2020 ballot
authors: Saja Hindi Is A Politics Reporter For The Denver Post. She'S An Award-Winning Reporter Who Has Previously Worked At The Fort Collins Coloradoan
The Loveland Reporter-Herald After Starting Her Journalism Career In North Carolina. She'S Covered Breaking News
summary:
A ballot measure meant to ensure that local communities don’t allow non-citizens to vote in their elections qualified for the 2020 ballot Thursday, but even if passed, it wouldn’t apply to dozens of Colorado’s largest cities.
Because it’s a constitutional amendment, it has to pass with 55% of the vote or more to take effect.
But even if the measure passes, Colorado’s more than 100 home-rule cities or towns — which have local control of their individual governments, as granted by the state constitution — won’t be subject to the same rules.
But opponents of Initiative 76 say the measure is misleading and feeding into anti-immigrant rhetoric.
“This is really to clear up that one item in the constitution to say not only who can vote but who can’t vote.”

The Space Weather Prediction Center will continue to update its forecast through the weekend.
The science behind the northern lights is a bit complicated — all you really need to know is that they are jaw-dropping beautiful.
Here's a helpful map from the Space Weather Prediction Center to help you determine your chances of seeing the Aurora Borealis this weekend.
The higher the number assigned to it, the greater your chances are to see the northern lights.

Two years after that agreement, we can definitively say the department still needs to be fixed.
Aurora’s existing review board – composed of four civilians, two officers, a lieutenant and a captain or commander — hasn’t met since Sept. 7, 2018.
Worse, the review board considers cases sent by the chief of police or by the officer involved in a disciplinary action.
Aurora must put in place a truly independent board, free to go where their concerns and community concerns take them.
It has professional and full-time employees dedicated to monitoring and reviewing police, sheriff and fire department operations and incidents.

title: Around 17K ballots sent to Aurora voters in Adams County contain error
summary:
ADAMS COUNTY, Colo. – More than 17,000 ballots for the upcoming November 2019 election were sent to voters in Aurora that contained an error, the county said Wednesday.
The county said that approximately 17,4000 ballots for the election were sent to Aurora voters living in Adams County that had an error in the voting instructions in the Aurora City Council at-large race.
The error instructed voters to vote for one at-large council member when they are actually supposed to be voting for two – instructions that were correctly defined on ballots sent to Aurora voters in Arapahoe County.
Adams County Clerk and Recorder Josh Zygielbaum took responsibility for the error at a news conference in Brighton on Wednesday afternoon.
Last year, more than 60,000 ballots were sent late to Adams County voters after one of the delivery trucks failed to deliver the ballots.

title: One person shot, injured at Town Center at Aurora
summary:

To keep people safe, we are working directly with the Aurora Police Department as they actively investigate this incident.
Guests, retailers and employees can call our security team 24 hours a day, 7 days a week at 303-344-4192 to request a security team member to meet them within the property, or for an escort to their vehicle.
For more information on the incident, please contact the Aurora Police Department directly at 303-627-3100.”This investigation is ongoing, and information will be updated as we receive it.

summary:

We play Colorado music every hour and The Local 303 spotlights the best from emerging and beloved artists in our scene.
His follow-up "Jungle" EP in 2019 showed off his diverse musical style with a heavy dose of hip hop and rap.
In the two-year run as a solo artist, Mitchell has been nominated for Best R&B Artist in Denver’s Westword Magazine, opened for Amber Mark on her national tour, and performed in several of Colorado’s most prestigious festivals.
With the magnetic allure of Bruno Mars and captivating charisma of Childish Gambino, Adiel Mitchell commands the room and seduces the audience with his seemingly effortless charm.

title: Longtime Aurora police officer will be first woman to lead the department
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
A longtime officer will lead the Aurora Police Department as interim chief while the city searches for candidates to fill the position permanently amid a series of high-profile controversies in the agency.
Division Chief Vanessa Wilson will step into the interim chief role Wednesday, becoming the first woman to lead the police department in Colorado’s third-largest city.
Aurora Police Chief Nick Metz announced in September that he would retire from the department on Dec. 31.
Wilson joined the Aurora Police Department in 1996 and Monday marked her 23rd anniversary with the agency.
Wilson takes the helm of the department as City Council members work to develop a new police oversight mechanism.

title: Man killed in Aurora shooting
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania
The Chattanooga Times Free Press In Tennessee. She'S Been A Reporter Since
She Helped The Newspaper Earn The Pulitzer Prize For Breaking News After A Mass Shooting At A Local Synagogue.
summary:
A man was fatally shot early Sunday in Aurora.
Officers found the man, who has not been identified, lying in the street in the 11000 block of East Colfax Street shortly after midnight.
The man had been shot in his upper body, according to Aurora police.
He was taken to a hospital and died at about 6 a.m. Police are investigating the incident as a homicide.
Anyone with information on the case is asked to call Aurora police at 303-739-6090.

title: In-N-Out Burger coming to Town Center at Aurora in 2020
summary:
The signs points to an In-N-Out Burger restaurant in Alhambra, California on August 30, 2018. Credit: FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP/Getty ImagesAURORA, Colo. — In a video posted on Twitter on Monday morning, the city of Aurora announced that In-N-Out Burger will be coming to the Town Center at Aurora in 2020.
In-N-Out is building a nearly 100,000-square-foot distribution center and a 150,000 square-foot office building in Colorado Springs.
The distribution center and offices will be built in the Victory Ridge mixed-use project on the north side of Colorado Springs.
When In-N-Out announced it was coming to Colorado, it was reported the distribution center could serve up to 50 restaurants within 350 miles of Colorado Springs, so more restaurants are expected.
A reason for a long-awaited expansion into Colorado is because In-N-Out did not have a distribution center nearby.

title: Man killed in shooting in Aurora on Christmas morning, police asking for information
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoAURORA -- Aurora police say a man was killed in a shooting early Christmas morning.
The shooting happened in the 17000 Block of East Kansas Place around 2:15 a.m.
When police arrived, they found a man inside a house with a gunshot wound.
If you have information or witnessed the shooting, please call 303-739-6106.
You can also submit a tip anonymously to Metro Denver Crime Stoppers at 720-913-7867 and be eligible for an award up to $2,000.

title: Investigations Into Aurora Officer Who Was Found Passed Out Drunk Come As The City Considers How To Police The Police
summary:
Nathan Meier, the officer who was behind the wheel while intoxicated, didn’t face any charges and is still working for the department.
Former U.S. Attorney John Walsh will conduct an independent investigation into the departments’ handling of Meier’s case, the city of Aurora announced on Monday night.
Meier was demoted after the incident and took a $20,000 pay cut, according to a statement from the Aurora Police Department.
The incident follows a string of other high-profile events over the last year involving the Aurora Police Department.
The city has been looking into replacing its review board with one that’s independent of the department.

title: “He’s a little intoxicated”: Body camera shows response to Aurora officer found passed out drunk in car in middle of road
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
One officer, Eugene VanDyk, can be heard commenting on Meier’s apparent intoxication in his body camera footage.
Other officers noted in their written reports that they smelled alcohol on Meier and in the car.
“Finding the balance between discipline and support is critically important … why?” Metz wrote.
Deputy Chief Paul O’Keefe — who will take over as interim chief when Metz retires Dec. 31 — was the first to arrive on the scene.
During an internal affairs investigation into the incident, Meier admitted he’d drunk vodka while on duty and blacked out.

title: Aurora police seek suspect in connection with Christmas Day fatal shooting
authors: Sam Tabachnik Is A Breaking News Reporter For The Denver Post
summary:
Aurora police identified a 36-year-old man as a suspect in connection with a fatal Christmas Day shooting.
Authorities are searching for Curtis Davis-Barnes, who drives a gray 2007 BMW 525 car with license plates CPL-238.
Police said he’s considered armed and dangerous and urged the public to call 911 if spotted.
Officers responded at 2:15 a.m. Wednesday to reports of a shooting in the 17000 block of East Kansas Place.
It was the second fatality in Aurora in a span of two hours.

title: On-duty Aurora police officer who passed out drunk while driving kept job, was never charged with DUI
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania
The Chattanooga Times Free Press In Tennessee. She'S Been A Reporter Since
She Helped The Newspaper Earn The Pulitzer Prize For Breaking News After A Mass Shooting At A Local Synagogue.
summary:
An on-duty, armed and uniformed Aurora police officer who passed out drunk while driving an unmarked patrol car in March but avoided criminal charges and kept his job is now facing new scrutiny from the 18th Judicial District Attorney’s Office.
The car was running, the vehicle was in gear and Meier’s foot was on the brake, according to the internal affairs summary.
Aurora police officers who responded smelled alcohol on Meier, according to the summary.
In a later interview with internal affairs, Meier admitted that he went home during his shift and drank vodka.
Meier is still employed as an Aurora police officer and is assigned to the Investigation Bureau for Economic Crimes and Pawn Detail.

title: Rent In Colorado: Prices Climbed In 2019
summary:
Rent costs are on the rise across the nation, according to the first National Rent Report of 2020, compiled by Apartment List.
Nationally, rent costs increased 1.4 percent from December 2018 to December 2019; however, some cities actually are bucking the trend and seeing rent costs fall.
Colorado is among states where rent costs increased in 2019.
According to the report, rent increased 1.6 percent from December 2018 to December 2019.
These are the top 10 cities with the fastest rent growth in the last five years:Stockton, California Colorado Springs, Colorado Mesa, Arizona Arlington, Texas Henderson, Nevada Tampa, Florida Aurora, Colorado Phoenix, Arizona Sacramento, California Anaheim, CaliforniaNationally, rent costs increased 11.3 percent since 2014.

title: UPS Customers In Colorado Report Waiting Weeks For Package Deliveries
summary:
AURORA, Colo. (CBS4) – Customers using UPS to receive packages in Colorado say they have waited more than two weeks in some cases for items to arrive at their home — but keep hearing or seeing status updates related to a facility in Aurora.
“I’ve been trying to get a hold of UPS to find out what’s been going on with my package,” said Sean McKinley, a Conifer resident.
“The vast majority of UPS packages are being delivered in accordance with the service level commitments made to our customers,” the company statement said.
They also say employees on the phone tell them the Aurora facility cannot be contacted internally within the company.
Residents impacted by this issue from UPS say FedEx and USPS have not reported the same delays and packages have arrived on time.

title: Aurora Cop Drives Drunk On Duty: Keeps Job, No Arrest
summary:
An Aurora police officer caught driving a department vehicle while drunk, on duty, in uniform, with his gun, remains on the job, a CBS4 Investigation has uncovered.
Officer Nate Meier, 48, of Parker, also never faced a criminal DUI case in connection with the March 2019 incident.
He was on duty, in uniform, operating an unmarked APD vehicle and was armed with his duty weapon at the time.
Several sources familiar with the Meier case told CBS4 Meier’s blood alcohol was more than five times the legal limit for DUI.
In his 2001 job application to the Aurora Police Department, Meier said he had previously worked for the Greeley Police department and had spent two years with the University of Northern Colorado Police Department.

title: Former Aurora police officer sentenced for stealing $65,000 from orphans, fallen officers funds
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
Roland Albert also will serve five years of probation and have to pay back with interest the more than $65,000 he stole from the Aurora Police Orphans Fund and Brotherhood for the Fallen Aurora.
The sentence was less severe than prosecutors hoped, but more than the probation sentence that Albert’s defense attorney argued for.
Caleb Albert is studying to be a police officer and said that his father’s crime was embarrassing.
Although the brotherhood organization recuperated about $4,000 from Albert, the orphan fund has not recuperated any of the stolen money.
Silver also said that Albert suffered from mental health problems stemming from the 2012 Aurora theater shooting.

title: Killings among Denver’s teens continue, even as city and community leaders try new solutions
authors: Elise Schmelzer Is The Public Safety Reporter At The Denver Post
Criminal Justice. She Previously Wrote For The Casper Star-Tribune In Wyoming
The Colorado Springs Gazette. She Studied Journalism
Spanish Literature At The University Of Missouri. When She'S Not Writing
She Disappears Into The Mountains To Hike
summary:
Eight teenagers were shot and killed in Denver last year, marking a second year of increased bloodshed among Denver’s young people.
City leaders held countless meetings to talk about solutions, and the mayor created a task force.
Easy solutions to the violence are hard to come by because the causes of the problem are varied and deeply rooted, city and community leaders said.
Aurora, too, is seeing an uptick in youth violence.
At a Denver City Council committee meeting last month, Denver City Attorney Kristin Bronson said the mayor’s task force on youth gun violence had an “aggressive work plan” for 2020.

title: Aurora deputy chief who responded to drunken officer says he is retiring
authors: Alex Burness Covers Politics For The Denver Post After Previous Work For The Boulder Daily Camera
Loveland Reporter-Herald. He Is A Maryland Native
summary:
Citing a recent change in “circumstances,” the man who was set to become interim chief of the Aurora Police Department in less than a week has announced he does not want the job and will retire in three months.
The announcement comes after Paul O’Keefe, a longtime department veteran and current deputy police chief, was the first APD official to arrive on the scene of a drunken, armed, on-duty Aurora officer, Nate Meier, who passed out while driving his patrol car.
APD Chief Nick Metz is stepping down after Dec. 31, and O’Keefe was slated to take over on an interim basis.
Chief Metz, in a recent email to colleagues, blasted coverage of the Meier scandal.
“I’m guessing many of you would agree with me that the inaccurate media spin this past week has been frustrating,” Metz wrote in his email, which Aurora officials released.

title: Suspect in fatal Christmas shooting in Aurora arrested
authors: Meg Wingerter Has Covered Education At The Denver Post Since February She Previously Worked At The Oklahoman
summary:
The Aurora Police Department reported Tuesday night they had arrested a suspect in a fatal Christmas day shooting.
Police had sought Curtis Davis-Barnes, 36, in connection with the shooting since Thursday.
The Arapahoe County Coroner’s Office also released the name of the victim in the shooting Tuesday.
Aarion Derritt, 39, was found shot at about 2:15 a.m. Dec. 25 in the 17000 block of East Kansas Place, according to the Aurora Sentinel.
The coroner’s office also identified the victim of an unrelated homicide reported about two hours before Derritt was found.

title: Aurora police: Woman dies after being found unresponsive; case considered homicide
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — The Aurora Police Department says a woman found unresponsive on Dec. 15 has since died and the case is now considered a homicide.
About 8:38 p.m. on Dec. 15, APD officers responded to 2402 S. Fraser St. to help Aurora Fire Rescue with an unresponsive woman.
The woman was placed on life support at the hospital,” APD said in a statement.
The woman was removed from life support Friday and died.
Anyone with information about the case should contact APD Agent M. Prince at: 303-739-6172.

title: Teen dies after shooting at Aurora apartment complex
summary:
UPDATE — On Wednesday morning, the Arapahoe County Coroner's Office identified the teenager who died in a shooting at the Aurora Hills Apartment complex on Monday evening as 16-year-old Frederick Robert.
...AURORA — Aurora police are continuing to investigate a fatal shooting from Monday night at an Aurora apartment complex.
The Aurora Police Department said the scene — Aurora Hills Apartments at E. Archer Place and Peoria — was very active as of 10:50 p.m.A male teenager was shot and died from his injuries, police said.
No other information was available on the teen, or a suspect.
Anybody with information on this shooting is asked to call Aurora dispatch at 303-627-3100.

title: 16-year-old killed in Aurora shooting identified
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — The Arapahoe County Coroner’s Office has identified the teenager killed in an Aurora shooting on Monday as 16-year-old Frederick Robert.
The shooting occurred shortly after 10:45 p.m. Monday at 11850 E. Maple Ave., which is home to the Aurora Hills apartments.
Robert was found inside an apartment with a gunshot wound.
Anyone with information about the shooting is asked to call Aurora Police Department Agent Hansen at: 303-627-3100.
Those wanting to remain anonymous can contact Metro Denver Crime Stoppers at: 720-913-7867.

title: Bloomberg unveils gun plan, receives endorsements at Aurora event
summary:
AURORA, CO – DECEMBER 05: Democratic presidential candidate, former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg waits to speak at an event to introduce his gun safety policy agenda at the Heritage Christian Center on December 5, 2019 in Aurora, Colorado.
The event, which was closed to the public, was held with survivors of gun violence and community leaders from across Colorado.
(Photo by Michael Ciaglo/Getty Images)Please enable Javascript to watch this videoAURORA, Colo. -- Democratic presidential contender Michael Bloomberg has unveiled a gun control policy just steps from the site of one of Colorado's worst mass shootings.
“That, I have no idea but it’s a wonderful state,” Bloomberg told St. George.

title: Woman fatally stabbed in Aurora on Christmas Day identified
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania
The Chattanooga Times Free Press In Tennessee. She'S Been A Reporter Since

summary:
A woman stabbed to death on Christmas Day in Aurora has been identified as 20-year-old Joy Delucio, according to the Arapahoe County Coroner’s Office.
Delucio was killed inside a mobile home around 12:20 a.m. in the 15700 block of East Colfax Avenue, according to Aurora police.
Both she and a man, who has not been identified, were found inside the mobile home with stab wounds.
The woman died at the scene, and the man was hospitalized in critical condition.
Aurora police said last week they were working to determine the relationship between the pair and what led to the stabbings.

title: StellarXplorers Announces 2020 National Finalists
summary:
AFA's StellarXplorers Announces 2020 National ChampionsThe Air Force Association (AFA) announced today the National Champions of the sixth season of its StellarXplorers National High School Space Challenge.
After four rounds of rigorous competition, Team "Rocket Men" of the Bergen County Technical School in Teterboro, New Jersey was crowned the 2020 National Champions.
The USAF STEM Program provided $19,000 in educational grants to these teams.
"Once again, over the course of another successful season, our competitors have shown they have the 'right stuff' to lead the future of US space," said Stephen K. Gourley, StellarXplorers program director.
StellarXplorers is an AFA program aimed at inspiring students to pursue education and careers in STEM fields using space system engineering.

title: Aurora deputy chief was first to respond to drunk officer who passed out in car
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania
The Chattanooga Times Free Press In Tennessee. She'S Been A Reporter Since

summary:
The soon-to-be interim chief of the Aurora Police Department was the first cop to arrive at the scene when an on-duty, armed officer passed out drunk while driving his police vehicle in March — that officer kept his job and avoided criminal charges.
Meier, who then held the rank of agent, was drifting in and out of consciousness, appeared disoriented and smelled of alcohol, officers who responded to the scene wrote in the reports.
Meier trying to focus on the noise, but was unsuccessful,” O’Keefe wrote in a report filed April 1.
Police decided not to test for alcohol consumption and did not seek a blood draw from Meier.
He was demoted from the rank of agent to officer, given an unpaid suspension and allowed to remain on the force.

title: Victim identified from Christmas Day shooting in Aurora
summary:
AURORA, Colo. – The Arapahoe County Coroner’s Office performed an autopsy on the victim who was killed Christmas morning at a residence in Aurora.
The victim has been identified as 39-year-old Aairon Earl Derritt, and the Arapahoe County Coroner’s Office classified his death as a homicide.
Aurora police released the following tweets in regards to the suspect in this case.
UPDATE: Curtis Davis-Barnes (DOB 101883) is wanted in this case for First Degree Murder.
If you see him immediately call 911 #APDNews pic.twitter.com/bpY6YlmBUE — Aurora Police Dept.

title: Juvenile shot at Town Center at Aurora Saturday
authors: Shelly Bradbury Is A Breaking News Reporter Who Joined The Denver Post In November She Previously Worked As A Crime Reporter At The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette In Pennsylvania
The Chattanooga Times Free Press In Tennessee. She'S Been A Reporter Since
She Helped The Newspaper Earn The Pulitzer Prize For Breaking News After A Mass Shooting At A Local Synagogue.
summary:
A boy was shot at the Town Center at Aurora on Saturday night.
Aurora police officers responded to the mall at 14200 East Alameda Ave. at about 7:09 p.m. for reports of shots fired, according to police.
They arrived to find a juvenile who’d been shot in the lower body.
He refused to cooperate with police, and it was not clear if he’d shot himself accidentally or was shot by another person, Aurora police said.
It was not immediately clear whether the shooting happened inside or outside the mall.

title: Driver dies at hospital after two-vehicle incident Monday in Aurora, police said
authors: Kieran Nicholson Covers Breaking News For The Denver Post. He Started At The Post In
California Streets. Nicholson Has Covered A Variety Of Beats Including Suburbs
summary:
A man died from injuries suffered in a two-vehicle incident Monday afternoon in Aurora, police said.
Emergency responders arrived on scene to find the driver of a pickup truck thrown from his vehicle, which had rolled, a news release said.
The driver was taken to University of Colorado Hospital where he died of his injuries.
The driver of the pickup was heading south when an “SUV pulled into his path causing the pickup to swerve and rollover ejecting the driver,” the release said.
The driver of the SUV is cooperating with investigators, police said.

title: Report of gunshots spark panic at Aurora mall Saturday night, but police say no shots fired
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — A quiet evening of shopping at the Town Center at Aurora mall turned to panic and confusion after a report of a shooting began to spread across the busy shopping center Saturday evening.
But Aurora police said there is no evidence that shots were fired.
Aurora mall shoppers panic after gunshot rumorAurora police said several people reported hearing gunshots in different parts of the mall.
But police again stressed that no credible evidence was found that someone had a gun or fired one inside or near the mall.
Town Center at Aurora remained open during its regular hours Saturday, but police had increased patrols in the area.

title: DA Launches Inquiry Into Case Of Aurora Officer Nathan Meier Found Drunk, Behind Wheel, On Duty
summary:
Arapahoe County District Attorney George Brauchler said Wednesday he has directed his staff to begin an inquiry seeking reports, evidence and answers from the Aurora Police Department.
That is after an on-duty Aurora officer, Nathan Meier, who was drunk, armed and behind the wheel of a department vehicle, was not charged for DUI or any other offense in March.
“We’re trying to evaluate what the Aurora Police department did.”Brauchler took action after a CBS4 investigation broke Tuesday surrounding an incident involving Meier.
Multiple sources familiar with the case said blood alcohol tests at the hospital showed Meier was at least five times the legal limit for DUI.
Asked if the Aurora police handling of Meier added up, Brauchler said it was “plausible up to a point.”Read APD’s full statement to CBS4:

title: Man sentenced to 160 years in prison for Aurora murder
summary:
A man who killed a 22-year-old and wounded a second person in a June 2018 shooting was sentenced to 160 years in prison in Arapahoe County District Court, according to a Monday news release from the 18th Judicial District Attorney’s Office.
A jury found Joseph Allen Collins Jr., 25, guilty in September of fatally shooting an unarmed Zachary Robinson, 22, and shooting his unnamed, 22-year-old friend in Aurora in June 2018.
Collins was convicted of second-degree murder, attempted second-degree murder, two counts of felony menacing and possession of a weapon by a previous offender.
Collins received a 96-year sentence for Robinson’s murder and 64 years for the attempted murder, the news release said.
Those sentences will run consecutively while sentences for the other convictions will run concurrently.

summary:

In light of this new reality, award shows should reconsider discouraging at-home viewing and stop creating rules that keep streaming platforms out of considerations for awards.
In the past few years, this rule has forced streaming companies like Netflix to do limited theatrical releases of select titles before they are released on the platform.
Movies distributed on streaming platforms are more democratic than theatrical releases because viewers can watch the film when and how they want and are not bound by theater etiquette.
Movies distributed on streaming platforms also deserve more recognition because the platforms take more risks.

title: Colorado snow totals (so far) as storm moves through Denver area
summary:
The city and surrounding areas saw our first measurable snow of the month, just in time to continue a streak of December snow that dates back to 1905.
About 3-5 inches was expected across Denver before the storm clears out late Saturday night.
(The mountains were enjoying the snow, too – Telluride Ski Resort reported 15 inches from Friday morning to Saturday morning.)
Full forecast: Snow cold and windy in Denver on SaturdayThe early snow reports Saturday were at or nearing that range.
Below are some of the latest snow totals, in inches, from across the state, via the National Weather Service's reporting stations.

title: Search continues for armed carjacking suspect in Arvada
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoARVADA, Colo. — Police are still searching for a male accused of firing shots at officers after he fled the scene of an armed carjacking.
A shelter-in-place was lifted Saturday night, even though the suspect was not located.
The incident began about 7:44 p.m. with an armed carjacking in the 5900 block of West 68th Avenue and Depew Street, according to Julie Glynn, an Arvada Police detective.
Arvada Police say a silver SUV pulled up into the victim's driveway and one man got out and started walking between the victim's vehicles.
Responding police located the vehicle, a gold Dodge Ram pickup truck, at West 58th Avenue and Kipling Street.

title: AURORA’S NEXT TOP COP: Residents outline qualities desired in next police chief
summary:
Those are just a few of stipulations Aurora residents outlined for the city’s next chief of police at a community forum Tuesday night.
Deputy Chief Paul O’Keefe was slated to replace Metz as interim chief after Metz announced his plans to retire in September.
As the city gauges public input on qualities of the next chief, Aurora City Councilwoman Nicole Johnston is moving forward with creating a task force that could craft an independent entity to review contentious police incidents in the city.
“No one has figured out yet how not to pick that politician,” Black, an Aurora cop of 32 years, told recruiters.
City Manager Jim Twombly is expected to select the next chief in late May or early June.

title: ‘Pothole Of The Month’ Club Encourages Drivers To Help Keep Aurora Roads Safe
summary:
– Early season snow means early season potholes around Colorado.
With the recent moisture, it is very likely more problem potholes will pop up.
Between November and April, anyone can submit a pothole repair request in the city using “Access Aurora.” Plus, there’s a potential reward.
“If it’s the biggest pothole that was fixed that month, you’re eligible for a $25 gift certificate,” McMinimee said.
Those who do not have access to the city’s app can also submit a problem pothole online or by phone.

summary:

Police said she was found with family in another city Saturday morning.

title: Dozens of Things You Can Still Do in Denver This Holiday Season
summary:
The metro area is lit for the season, with holiday markets, holiday productions and holiday light shows all over.
Through January 5: Camp Christmas: This 10,000-square-foot immersive art experience explores holiday rituals and imagery from across the globe.
Through January 30: DIA Ice Skating Rink: Got a few hours to kill before your flight?
Through February 3: Downtown Denver Ice Skating Rink: Bring your own skates and practice your triple axel for free at this outdoor rink now entering its tenth year.
Through February 17: Winterskate: It's not just ice skating at this 6,500-square-foot rink; there are also free carriage rides, Christmas music and plenty of tasty holiday treats.

title: Pedestrian who died after getting hit by multiple vehicles is identified
summary:
AURORA, Colo. — A pedestrian who was killed Wednesday night after getting hit by at least two vehicles in Aurora has been identified.
The Adams County Coroner's Office identified the victim as 26-year-old Rahjeem Jaleo Edwards, of Aurora.
An investigation revealed the pedestrian was walking along East Smith Road when they were struck by one vehicle and then another vehicle, APD said.
It was also reported that a third vehicle was involved but that driver did not remain on scene, according to APD.
Anyone with information on the incident is asked to contact the Aurora Police Traffic Section at 720-432-5095.

title: Aurora Police investigating fatal vehicle vs. pedestrian crash
summary:
AURORA – Police are investigating a fatal vehicle vs. pedestrian crash that happened overnight.
According to Aurora Police, the crash happened west of E. Colfax Ave. and N. Laredo St.
The pedestrian, an adult male, was pronounced dead at the scene.
According to police, the driver was traveling westbound on Colfax Avenue and just passed Laredo Street, when he struck the pedestrian.
The crash is still being investigated by Aurora Police, and the name of the pedestrian is not being released at this time.
